form.longName: PhenX PX540602 - Sensitivity To Reward And Punishment Child
form.preferredDefinition: The child version of the behavioral inhibition system (BIS)/behavioral activation system (BAS) scale is a self- or proxy-administered 24-item questionnaire that measures individual differences in motivation. Respondents indicate how much they agree or disagree with the statements on a four-point scale (very true to not true). Scores can be derived for three behavioral activation system subscales (Drive, Fun Seeking, and Reward Responsiveness) and one behavioral inhibition system subscale. This scale is based on the original BIS/BAS system, which was later revised by Gray and McNaughton (2000).

module.longName: Sensitivity to Reward and Punishment - Child
module.preferredDefinition: Sensitivity to Reward and Punishment - Child

question.questionText: 1. I do not become fearful or nervous, even when something bad happens to me. (not_fearful_when_bad_happens)
2. I do everything to get the things that I want. (do_everything_to_get_things)
3. When I am doing well at something, I like to keep doing this. (like_to_keep_doing)
4. I am always willing to try something new, when I think it will be fun. (pxt540602_willing_to_try_something_new)
5. I feel excited and full of energy when I get something that I want. (excited_and_full_of_energy)
6. I am hurt when people scold me or tell me that I do something wrong. (hurt_when_scolded)
7. When I want something, I usually go all the way to get it. (go_all_the_way)
8. I often do things for no other reason than that they might be fun. (do_things_for_fun)
9. When I see an opportunity to get something that I want, I go for it right away. (go_for_opportunities_right_away)
10. I feel pretty upset when I think that someone is angry with me. (upset_when_someone_is_angry)
11. I get really excited when I see an opportunity to get something I like. (excited_about_opportunity)
12. I often do things on the spur of the moment. (spur_of_the_moment)
13. I usually get very tense when I think something unpleasant is going to happen. (tense_when_something_unpleasant_happens)
14. I get thrilled when good things happen to me. (thrilled_when_good_things_happen)
15. I feel worried when I think I have done poorly at something. (worried_when_do_poorly)
16. I crave for excitement and new sensations. (crave_for_excitement)
17. Nobody can stop me when I want something. (nobody_can_stop_me)
18. I am very fearful compared to my friends. (fearful_compared_to_my_friends)
19. I get very excited when I would win a contest. (excited_about_winning_contest)
20. I worry about making mistakes. (pxt540602_worry_about_making_mistakes)

Scoring : Items 1 and 18 are reversescored. Add up the scores associated with each answer response to obtain scores for the individual subscales listed below. *0= not true *1= somewhat true *2= true *3= very true *BAS Drive: 2, 7, 9, 17 *BAS Fun Seeking: 4, 8, 12, 16 *BAS Reward Responsiveness: 3, 5, 11, 14, 19 *BIS: 1, 6, 10, 13, 15, 18, 20 (scoring_540602)

protocol.longName: Sensitivity to Reward and Punishment - Child
protocol.preferredDefinition: The child version of the behavioral inhibition system (BIS)/behavioral activation system (BAS) scale is a self- or proxy-administered 24-item questionnaire that measures individual differences in motivation. Respondents indicate how much they agree or disagree with the statements on a four-point scale (very true to not true). Scores can be derived for three behavioral activation system subscales (Drive, Fun Seeking, and Reward Responsiveness) and one behavioral inhibition system subscale. This scale is based on the original BIS/BAS system, which was later revised by Gray and McNaughton (2000).

form.longName: PhenX PX540101 - Community Risk And Protective Factors
form.preferredDefinition: The protocol includes 33 self-administered questions from the Communities That Care Youth Survey. The protocol includes eight subscales: Low Neighborhood Attachment (three items on a 4-point scale), Community Disorganization (five items on a 4-point scale), Transitions and Mobility (four items on a 5-point scale), Perceived Availability of Handguns (one item on a 4-point scale), Opportunities for Prosocial Involvement (five items on a 4-point scale), Rewards for Prosocial Involvement (three items on a 4-point scale), Perceived Availability of Drugs (four items on a 4-point scale), and Laws and Norms Favorable to Drug Use (seven items on a 4-point scale).

headerInstruction.text: This is not a test, so there are no right or wrong answers we would like you to work quickly, so that you can finish. Mark (the BIG) YES! if you think the statement is definitely true for you. Mark (the little) yes if you think the statement i..TRUNCATED

question.questionText: 1. If you wanted to get some beer, wine, or hard liquor (for example, vodka, whiskey, or gin), how easy would it be for you to get some? (get_beer_wine_liquor)
2. If you wanted to get some cigarettes, how easy would it be for you to get some? (get_cigarettes)
3. If a kid smoked marijuana in your neighborhood, would he or she be caught by the police? (kid_smoked_marijuana_get_caught)
4. If you wanted to get a drug like cocaine, LSD, or amphetamines, how easy would it be for you to get some? (get_cocaine_lsd_amphetamines)
5. If a kid drank some beer, wine, or hard liquor (for example, vodka, whiskey, or gin) in your neighborhood, would he or she be caught by the police? (kid_drank_get_caught)
6. If you wanted to get a handgun, how easy would it be for you to get one? (get_handgun)
7. If a kid carried a handgun in your neighborhood would he or she be caught by the police? (kid_carried_handgun_get_caught)
8. If you wanted to get some marijuana, how easy would it be for you to get some? (marijuana_how_easy_for_you)
9. If a kid smoked a cigarette in your neighborhood would he or she be caught by the police? (kid_smoked_cigarette_get_caught)
10a. How wrong would most adults (over 21) in your neighborhood think it is for kids your age to use marijuana? (adults_attitude_kid_using_marijuana)
10b. How wrong would most adults (over 21) in your neighborhood think it is for kids your age to drink alcohol? (adults_attitude_kid_using_alcohol)
10c. How wrong would most adults (over 21) in your neighborhood think it is for kids your age to smoke cigarettes? (adults_attitude_kid_using_cigarettes)
11. If I had to move, I would miss the neighborhood I now live in. (would_miss_the_neighborhood)
12. My neighbors notice when I am doing a good job and let me know about it. (neighbors_notice_good_job)
13. I like my neighborhood. (like_my_neighborhood)
14. There are lots of adults in my neighborhood I could talk to about something important. (talk_to_adults_in_neighborhood)
15a. How much do each of the following statements describe your neighborhood? Crime and/or drug selling (statements_describe_neighborhood_crime)
15b. How much do each of the following statements describe your neighborhood? Fights (statements_describe_neighborhood_fights)
15c. How much do each of the following statements describe your neighborhood? Lots of empty or abandoned buildings (statements_describe_neighborhood_abandoned_buildings)
15d. How much do each of the following statements describe your neighborhood? Lots of graffiti (statements_describe_neighborhood_graffiti)
16. How many times have you changed homes since kindergarten? (times_changed_homes_since_kindergarten)
17. There are people in my neighborhood who are proud of me when I do something well. (people_in_neighborhood_proud)
18a. Which of the following activities for people your age are available in your community? Sports teams (activities_in_community_sports_teams)
18b. Which of the following activities for people your age are available in your community? Scouting (activities_in_community_scouting)
18c. Which of the following activities for people your age are available in your community? Boys and girls clubs (activities_in_community_boysgirls_clubs)
18d. Which of the following activities for people your age are available in your community? 4H clubs (activities_in_community_4h_clubs)
18e. Which of the following activities for people your age are available in your community? Service Clubs (activities_in_community_service_clubs)
19. Have you changed schools (including changing from elementary to middle or middle to high school) in the past year? (changed_schools_in_past_year)
20. I feel safe in my neighborhood. (feel_safe_in_neighborhood)
21. How many times have you changed schools (including changing from elementary to middle or middle to high school) since kindergarten? (changed_schools_since_kindergarten)
22. I'd like to get out of my neighborhood. (like_get_out_of_neighborhood)
23. Have you changed homes in the past year? (changed_homes_in_past_year)
24. There are people in my neighborhood who encourage me to do my best. (people_in_neighborhood_who_encourage)
Scoring (scoring)

protocol.preferredDefinition: The protocol includes 33 self-administered questions from the Communities That Care Youth Survey. The protocol includes eight subscales: Low Neighborhood Attachment (three items on a 4-point scale), Community Disorganization (five items on a 4-point scale), Transitions and Mobility (four items on a 5-point scale), Perceived Availability of Handguns (one item on a 4-point scale), Opportunities for Prosocial Involvement (five items on a 4-point scale), Rewards for Prosocial Involvement (three items on a 4-point scale), Perceived Availability of Drugs (four items on a 4-point scale), and Laws and Norms Favorable to Drug Use (seven items on a 4-point scale).

form.preferredDefinition: The Disruptive Behavior Disorders Rating Scale (DBDRS) is a proxy-administered (parent or teacher) questionnaire that is based on Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, 4th Edition (DSM-IV) diagnostic criteria for attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), oppositional-defiant disorder (ODD), and conduct disorder (CD). As such, it includes subscales for inattention, hyperactivity-impulsivity, oppositional defiance, and conduct disorder. Each item is rated on a 4-point scale ranging from 0 ("not at all") to 3 ("very much"). Users can generate composite scores or scores for individual subscales.

question.questionText: Has run away from home overnight at least twice while living in parental or parental surrogate home (or once without returning for a lengthy period) (run_away_from_home_overnight)
Often argues with adults (often_argues_with_adults)
Often lies to obtain goods or favors or to avoid obligations (i.e., "cons" others) (often_lies)
Has been physically cruel to people (physically_cruel_to_people)
Has stolen items of nontrivial value without confronting a victim (e.g., shoplifting, but without breaking and entering forgery) (stolen_items_without_confronting_victim)
Often truant from school, beginning before age 13 years (often_truant_from_school)
Is often spiteful or vindictive (often_spiteful_or_vindictive)
Often blames others for his or her mistakes or misbehavior (blames_others_for_mistakes)
Has deliberately destroyed others' property (other than by fire setting) (deliberately_destroyed_property)
Often actively defies or refuses to comply with adults' requests or rules (defies_adults_requests_rules)
Often initiates physical fights with others who do not live in his or her household (e.g., peers at school or in the neighborhood) (initiates_physical_fights)
Is often angry and resentful (often_angry_and_resentful)
Is often touchy or easily annoyed by others (touchy_or_annoyed_by_others)
Often loses temper (often_loses_temper)
Has forced someone into sexual activity (forced_someone_into_sexual_activity)
Often bullies, threatens, or intimidates others (often_bullies_threatens_or_intimidates)
Has been physically cruel to animals (physically_cruel_to_animals)
Often stays out at night despite parental prohibitions, beginning before age 13 years (stays_out_at_night)
Often deliberately annoys people (often_deliberately_annoys_people)
Has stolen while confronting a victim (e.g., mugging, purse snatching, extortion, armed robbery) (stolen_confronting_victim)
Has deliberately engaged in fire setting with the intention of causing serious damage (engaged_in_fire_setting)
Has broken into someone else's house, building, or car (broken_into_house_building_car)
Has used a weapon that can cause serious physical harm to others (e.g., a bat, brick, broken bottle, knife, gun) (used_weapon)

protocol.preferredDefinition: The Disruptive Behavior Disorders Rating Scale (DBDRS) is a proxy-administered (parent or teacher) questionnaire that is based on Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, 4th Edition (DSM-IV) diagnostic criteria for attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), oppositional-defiant disorder (ODD), and conduct disorder (CD). As such, it includes subscales for inattention, hyperactivity-impulsivity, oppositional defiance, and conduct disorder. Each item is rated on a 4-point scale ranging from 0 ("not at all") to 3 ("very much"). Users can generate composite scores or scores for individual subscales.

form.longName: PhenX PX530101 - Cognitive Flexibility Dimensional Change Card Sort Old
form.preferredDefinition: The Dimensional Change Card Sort (DCCS) Border Version is an interviewer-administered task that measures the flexible use of rules to govern behavior as a means of providing an index of executive function development. In this task, the assessor asks the participant to sort bivalent test cards according to a randomly changing dimension (e.g., color or shape). The dimension by which to sort is indicated by the presence or absence of a border on the card. The Dimensional Change Card Sort task is a freely available, simplified version of the Wisconsin Card Sort test. For more information about the Wisconsin Card Sort test, please refer to www.cognitiveatlas.org/task/id/tsk_4a57abb949f21|Cognitive Atlas Interpretation.

headerInstruction.text: Summary of the Dimensional Change Card Sort (DCCS) Border Version .The Dimensional Change Card Sort (DCCS) Border Version makes use of two different styles of bivalent cards, displaying for example a red boat and blue rabbit. The test cards ad..TRUNCATED

module.longName: Cognitive Flexibility (Dimensional Change Card Sort) - Older Children, Adolescents, and Adults
module.preferredDefinition: Cognitive Flexibility (Dimensional Change Card Sort) - Older Children, Adolescents, and Adults

question.questionText: Dimension used for sorting border cards. (dimension_sorting_border_cards)
Number of cards correctly sorted: __________ (number_cards_correctly_sorted)
Standard and Border version administered? (standard_border_version_administered)
Combined (Standard and Border version) score. (combined_score)

validValue.meaningText: Participant failed the pre-switch phase of the standard version.
validValue.description: Participant failed the pre-switch phase of the standard version.

validValue.meaningText: Participant passed the pre-switch phase of the standard version, but failed the post-switch phase.
validValue.description: Participant passed the pre-switch phase of the standard version, but failed the post-switch phase.

validValue.meaningText: Participant passed the pre-switch and post-switch phases of the standard version, but failed the border version.
validValue.description: Participant passed the pre-switch and post-switch phases of the standard version, but failed the border version.

validValue.meaningText: Participant passed the pre-switch and post-switch phases of the standard version and passed the border version.
validValue.description: Participant passed the pre-switch and post-switch phases of the standard version and passed the border version.

question.questionText: Scoring: Participants who correctly sort nine or more of the twelve test cards are considered to have passed the task. If both the DCCS Standard Version and DCCS Border Version are administered, an alternative scoring scheme is as follows: Score of 0 Participant failed the preswitch phase of the standard version. Score of 1 Participant passed the preswitch phase of the standard version, but failed the postswitch phase. Score of 2 Participant passed the preswitch and postswitch phases of the standard version, but failed the border version. Score of 3 Participant passed the preswitch and postswitch phases of the standard version and passed the border version. (scoring_530101)

protocol.longName: Cognitive Flexibility (Dimensional Change Card Sort) - Older Children, Adolescents, and Adults
protocol.preferredDefinition: The Dimensional Change Card Sort (DCCS) Border Version is an interviewer-administered task that measures the flexible use of rules to govern behavior as a means of providing an index of executive function development. In this task, the assessor asks the participant to sort bivalent test cards according to a randomly changing dimension (e.g., color or shape). The dimension by which to sort is indicated by the presence or absence of a border on the card. The Dimensional Change Card Sort task is a freely available, simplified version of the Wisconsin Card Sort test. For more information about the Wisconsin Card Sort test, please refer to www.cognitiveatlas.org/task/id/tsk_4a57abb949f21|Cognitive Atlas Interpretation.
